column2: The contribution of the sectors covered by the EU ETS with respect to the EU Climate ambition should be of -62 % compared to 2005
column5: The implementation of TA3.23 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.13, as reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the EU ETS sectors can contribute to achieving the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from transport. This is because the transport sector is one of the main contributors to greenhouse gas emissions, and reducing emissions from the EU ETS sectors can help to achieve the overall reduction target.

column2: Reduce the generation of food waste in processing and manufacturing by 10% in comparison to 2020
column5: The implementation of TA3.24 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.15, as reducing food waste can contribute to achieving the target of increasing the share of renewable energy in the energy mix. This is because reducing food waste can lead to a reduction in the energy needed to produce, process, and transport food, which can in turn lead to an increase in the share of renewable energy in the energy mix.

column2: Reduce the generation of food waste per capita, jointly in retail and other distribution of food, in restaurants and food services and in households, by 30 % in comparison 2020
column5: The implementation of TA3.25 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.15, as reducing food waste can contribute to achieving the target of increasing the share of renewable energy in the energy mix. This is because reducing food waste can lead to a reduction in the energy needed to produce, process, and transport food, which can in turn lead to an increase in the share of renewable energy in the energy mix.

column2: All packaging shall be recyclable
column5: The implementation of TA3.27 is likely to have a negative impact on TA2.21, as making all packaging recyclable may require significant investments in new technologies and infrastructure, which could lead to increased energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions in the short term.

column2: The plastic part in packaging shall contain the following minimum percentage of recycled content
column5: The implementation of TA3.28 is likely to have a negative impact on TA2.21, as increasing the percentage of recycled content in packaging may require significant investments in new technologies and infrastructure, which could lead to increased energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions in the short term.

column2: Member States shall take measures to achieve a sustained reduction in the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags
column5: The implementation of TA3.29 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.21, as reducing the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags can contribute to achieving the target of reducing energy consumption. This is because plastic carrier bags are often made from non-renewable resources and their production and disposal can lead to greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: Each Member State shall reduce the packaging waste generated per capita, as compared to the packaging waste generated per capita in 2018
column5: The implementation of TA3.30 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.21, as reducing packaging waste can contribute to achieving the target of reducing energy consumption. This is because packaging waste can lead to energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions during production, transportation, and disposal.

column2: Member States shall take the necessary measures to attain the recycling targets of 65% by weight of all packaging waste generated by 31 December 2025
column5: The implementation of TA3.31 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.21, as increasing recycling rates can contribute to achieving the target of reducing energy consumption. This is because recycling can reduce the need for virgin materials and energy-intensive production processes.

column2: Member States shall take the necessary measures to attain a recycling target of 50% of plastic by weight of plastic contained in packaging waste generated by 31 December 2025
column5: The implementation of TA3.32 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.21, as increasing recycling rates can contribute to achieving the target of reducing energy consumption. This is because recycling can reduce the need for virgin materials and energy-intensive production processes.

column2: Member States shall take the necessary measures to attain a recycling target of 25% of wood by weight of wood contained in packaging waste generated by 31 December 2025
column5: The implementation of TA3.33 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.21, as increasing recycling rates can contribute to achieving the target of reducing energy consumption. This is because recycling can reduce the need for virgin materials and energy-intensive production processes.

column2: Member States shall take the necessary measures to attain a recycling target of 70% of ferrous metals by weight of ferrous metals contained in packaging waste generated by 31 December 2025
column5: The implementation of TA3.34 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.21, as increasing recycling rates can contribute to achieving the target of reducing energy consumption. This is because recycling can reduce the need for virgin materials and energy-intensive production processes.

column2: Member States shall take the necessary measures to attain a recycling target of 50% of aluminium by weight of aluminium contained in packaging waste generated by 31 December 2025
column5: The implementation of TA3.35 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.21, as increasing recycling rates can contribute to achieving the target of reducing energy consumption. This is because recycling can reduce the need for virgin materials and energy-intensive production processes.

column2: Member States shall take the necessary measures to attain a recycling target of 70% of glass by weight of glass contained in packaging waste generated by 31 December 2025
column5: The implementation of TA3.36 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.21, as increasing recycling rates can contribute to achieving the target of reducing energy consumption. This is because recycling can reduce the need for virgin materials and energy-intensive production processes.

column2: Member States shall take the necessary measures to attain a recycling target of 75% of paper and cardboard by weight of paper and cardboard contained in packaging waste generated by 31 December 2025
column5: The implementation of TA3.37 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.21, as increasing recycling rates can contribute to achieving the target of reducing energy consumption. This is because recycling can reduce the need for virgin materials and energy-intensive production processes.

column2: Each vehicle belonging to a vehicle type that is type-approved as of [the first day of the month following 72 months after the date of entry into force of this Regulation] under Regulation (EU) 2018/858 shall be constructed so that it is: (a) reusable/recyclable to a minimum of 85% by mass
column3: (b) reusable/recoverable to a minimum of 95 % by mass
column6: The implementation of TA3.38 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.14, as increasing the recyclability and recoverability of vehicles can contribute to achieving the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from transport. This is because recycling and recovering vehicles can reduce the need for virgin materials and energy-intensive production processes.

column2: The plastic contained in each vehicle type that is type-approved as of [the first day of the month following 72 months after the date of entry into force of the Regulation] under Regulation (EU) 2018/858 shall contain a minimum of 25 % of plastic recycled by weight from post-consumer plastic waste
column5: The implementation of TA3.48 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.14, as increasing the use of recycled plastic in vehicles can contribute to achieving the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from transport. This is because using recycled plastic can reduce the need for virgin materials and energy-intensive production processes.

column2: At least 25% of the target set out in the first subparagraph shall be achieved by including plastics recycled from end-of-life vehicles in the vehicle type concerned
column5: The implementation of TA3.49 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.14, as increasing the use of recycled plastic from end-of-life vehicles can contribute to achieving the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from transport. This is because using recycled plastic can reduce the need for virgin materials and energy-intensive production processes.

column2: Member States shall ensure that the following targets are met by the waste management operators: (a) the reuse and recovery, as calculated together, shall be a minimum of 95 %, by average weight per vehicle, excluding batteries, and year
column3: (b) the reuse and recycling, as calculated together, shall be a minimum of 85 %, by average weight per vehicle, excluding batteries, and year
column6: The implementation of TA3.50 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.14, as increasing the reuse and recycling rates of vehicles can contribute to achieving the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from transport. This is because recycling and reusing vehicles can reduce the need for virgin materials and energy-intensive production processes.

column2: By 31 December 2025, each Member State shall agree to establish a framework for cooperation on joint projects with one or more other Member States for the production of renewable energy
column5: The implementation of TA2.11 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.23, as increasing cooperation on joint projects for renewable energy production can contribute to achieving the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the EU ETS sectors. This is because joint projects can lead to increased investment in renewable energy and reduced costs, making it more competitive with fossil fuels.

column2: The amount of renewable fuels and renewable electricity supplied to the transport sector leads to a: (i) share of renewable energy within the final consumption of energy in the transport sector of at least 29 % by 2030
column3: or (ii) GHG intensity reduction of at least 14.5 % by 2030
column6: The implementation of TA2.13 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.24, as increasing the use of renewable fuels and electricity in transport can contribute to achieving the target of reducing food waste. This is because renewable energy can reduce the need for fossil fuels, which are often used in food production and transportation, and can also reduce greenhouse gas emissions from transport.

column2: Each Member State shall increase the share of renewable energy in the heating and cooling sector by at least 0.8 percentage points as an annual average calculated for the period 2021 to 2025 and by at least 1.1 percentage points as an annual average calculated for the period 2026 to 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.14 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.25, as increasing the use of renewable energy in heating and cooling can contribute to achieving the target of reducing food waste per capita. This is because renewable energy can reduce the need for fossil fuels, which are often used in food production and transportation, and can also reduce greenhouse gas emissions from heating and cooling.

column2: By 2022, achieve 18% of the total increase in the share of energy from renewable sources between that Member State’s binding 2020 national target, and its contribution to the 2030 target of the share of energy from renewable sources in gross final consumption of energy
column5: The implementation of TA2.15 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.27, as increasing the use of renewable energy can contribute to achieving the target of making all packaging recyclable. This is because renewable energy can reduce the need for fossil fuels, which are often used in packaging production, and can also reduce greenhouse gas emissions from packaging production.

column2: Member States shall endeavour to increase the share of renewable sources in the amount of energy sources used for final energy and non-energy purposes in the industry sector by an indicative increase of at least 1.6 percentage points as an annual average calculated for the periods 2021 to 2025 and 2026 to 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.16 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.28, as increasing the use of renewable energy in industry can contribute to achieving the target of increasing the percentage of recycled content in packaging. This is because renewable energy can reduce the need for fossil fuels, which are often used in packaging production, and can also reduce greenhouse gas emissions from packaging production.

column2: A target of 15% electricity interconnection for 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.17 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.29, as increasing electricity interconnection can contribute to achieving the target of reducing the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags. This is because increased electricity interconnection can lead to increased use of renewable energy, which can reduce the need for fossil fuels and lower greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: Member States shall collectively ensure a reduction of energy consumption of at least 11.7% in 2030 compared to the projections of the 2020 EU Reference Scenario
column5: The implementation of TA2.21 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.30, as reducing energy consumption can contribute to achieving the target of reducing packaging waste. This is because reducing energy consumption can lead to reduced production and transportation of packaging, which can in turn lead to reduced waste.

column2: Member States shall collectively ensure a reduction of energy consumption of at least 11.7% in 2030 compared to the projections of the 2020 EU Reference Scenario
column5: The implementation of TA2.22 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.31, as reducing energy consumption can contribute to achieving the target of increasing recycling rates. This is because reducing energy consumption can lead to reduced production and transportation of packaging, which can in turn lead to increased recycling rates.

column2: Member States shall make efforts to collectively contribute to the indicative Union primary energy consumption target amounting to no more than 992.5 Mtoe in 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.23 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.32, as reducing primary energy consumption can contribute to achieving the target of increasing recycling rates of plastic. This is because reducing primary energy consumption can lead to reduced production and transportation of packaging, which can in turn lead to increased recycling rates.

column2: Each Member State shall ensure that at least 3% of the total floor area of heated and/or cooled buildings that are owned by public bodies is renovated each year to be transformed into at least nearly zero-energy buildings or zero-emission buildings
column5: The implementation of TA2.24 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.33, as increasing the renovation rate of public buildings can contribute to achieving the target of increasing recycling rates of wood. This is because renovating buildings can lead to increased use of recycled materials, which can in turn lead to increased recycling rates.

column2: Reduce buildings’ final energy consumption by 14%
column5: The implementation of TA2.25 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.34, as reducing final energy consumption can contribute to achieving the target of increasing recycling rates of ferrous metals. This is because reducing energy consumption can lead to reduced production and transportation of packaging, which can in turn lead to increased recycling rates.

column2: At least double the annual energy renovation rate of residential and non-residential buildings by 2030 and to foster deep energy renovations
column5: The implementation of TA2.26 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.35, as increasing the energy renovation rate can contribute to achieving the target of increasing recycling rates of aluminium. This is because renovating buildings can lead to increased use of recycled materials, which can in turn lead to increased recycling rates.

column2: Reduce buildings’ energy consumption for heating and cooling by 18% compared to 2015 levels by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.28 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.36, as reducing energy consumption for heating and cooling can contribute to achieving the target of increasing recycling rates of glass. This is because reducing energy consumption can lead to reduced production and transportation of packaging, which can in turn lead to increased recycling rates.

column2: Member states will have to renovate 16% of worst-performing non-residential buildings by 2030 and, by 2033, the worst-performing 26% through minimum energy performance requirements
column5: The implementation of TA2.29 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.37, as increasing the renovation rate of non-residential buildings can contribute to achieving the target of increasing recycling rates of paper and cardboard. This is because renovating buildings can lead to increased use of recycled materials, which can in turn lead to increased recycling rates.

column2: The national measures will have to ensure that at least 55% of the decrease of the average primary energy use is achieved through the renovation of the worst-performing buildings
column5: The implementation of TA2.33 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.38, as increasing the renovation rate of worst-performing buildings can contribute to achieving the target of reducing the number of vehicles that are not reusable or recyclable. This is because renovating buildings can lead to increased use of recycled materials, which can in turn lead to reduced waste and increased recycling rates.

column2: Member States are required to achieve cumulative end-use energy savings from 2021 to 2030, equivalent to new annual savings of at least 0.8% of final energy consumption in 2021-2023, at least 1.3% in 2024-2025, 1.5% in 2026-2027 and 1.9% in 2028-2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.41 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.49, as increasing energy savings can contribute to achieving the target of increasing the use of recycled plastic from end-of-life vehicles. This is because reducing energy consumption can lead to reduced production and transportation of vehicles, which can in turn lead to increased recycling rates.

column2: By 2030, the share of renewable energy in the electricity mix should double to 55-60%, and projections show a share of around 84% by 2050
column5: The implementation of TA2.37 is likely to have a positive impact on TA3.50, as increasing the share of renewable energy can contribute to achieving the target of increasing the reuse and recycling rates of vehicles. This is because renewable energy can reduce the need for fossil fuels, which are often used in vehicle production, and can also reduce greenhouse gas emissions from vehicle production.
